title: Evolution in a big city - Jason Munshi-South

multiple-choice.question: What type of salamanders are found in the forested hillside in Northern Manhattan?

options.label: A
options.text: Eastern newt

options.label: B
options.text: Northern dusky salamanders

options.label: C
options.text: Red-backed salamander

options.label: D
options.text: Spotted salamander

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason for the isolation of the northern dusky salamander population in New York City?

options.label: A
options.text: Habitat destruction

options.label: B
options.text: Pollution

options.label: C
options.text: Infrastructure development, such as bridges

options.label: D
options.text: Climate change

multiple-choice.question: How are the researchers studying the spread of coyotes in New York City?

options.label: A
options.text: By tracking their footprints

options.label: B
options.text: By using automatic camera traps

options.label: C
options.text: By conducting surveys among residents

options.label: D
options.text: By analyzing their howls

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary goal of studying the white-footed mouse in New York City?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand their behavior

options.label: B
options.text: To control their population

options.label: C
options.text: To use them as a model to understand how species adapt to urban environments

options.label: D
options.text: To study their diet

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of comparing the DNA of white-footed mice from different parks in New York City?

options.label: A
options.text: They show no genetic differences

options.label: B
options.text: They show minor genetic differences

options.label: C
options.text: They show significant genetic differences, allowing researchers to determine which park a mouse came from

options.label: D
options.text: They show only physical differences

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of sequencing thousands of genes from city mice and comparing them to genes from country mice?

options.label: A
options.text: To identify the genetic basis of their physical differences

options.label: B
options.text: To understand how their biology is changing in response to urbanization

options.label: C
options.text: To develop new methods for genetic analysis

options.label: D
options.text: To study the evolution of mice in general

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential consequence of a single base-pair change in a gene that leads to increased fitness in a mouse?

options.label: A
options.text: The change will be neutral and have no effect on the population

options.label: B
options.text: The change will be detrimental and decrease the population size

options.label: C
options.text: The change will spread quickly in the population

options.label: D
options.text: The change will only affect the individual mouse

multiple-choice.question: What do the genes that are most different between city and country mice encode for?

options.label: A
options.text: Only physical traits

options.label: B
options.text: Only behavioral traits

options.label: C
options.text: Traits such as immune response, metabolism, and heavy-metal tolerance

options.label: D
options.text: Only genetic traits

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to study the adaptation of species to urban environments?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand the impact of urbanization on human health

options.label: B
options.text: To develop new methods for genetic analysis

options.label: C
options.text: To understand how species can thrive in urban environments and to inform conservation efforts

options.label: D
options.text: To study the evolution of species in general

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's main message to the audience?

options.label: A
options.text: To appreciate the beauty of New York City's parks

options.label: B
options.text: To recognize the importance of conservation efforts in urban environments

options.label: C
options.text: To encourage the audience to look at their parks in a new way and appreciate the wildlife that lives there

options.label: D
options.text: To support the development of new infrastructure in New York City

title: How containerization shaped the modern world - Sir Harold Evans

multiple-choice.question: What occupation did Malcolm McLean hold during the Great Depression that led him to observe the inefficiencies of the shipping industry?

options.label: A
options.text: Stevedore at the docks in Hoboken, New Jersey

options.label: B
options.text: 24-year-old truck driver transporting cotton bales from Fayetteville, North Carolina to Hoboken, New Jersey

options.label: C
options.text: Ship captain sailing from Port Newark to Europe

options.label: D
options.text: Warehouse manager in Fayetteville, North Carolina

multiple-choice.question: What issue did Malcolm McLean face while waiting at the docks in Hoboken, which ultimately led to his idea of containerization?

options.label: A
options.text: Concern for the safety of his cargo

options.label: B
options.text: Frustration with the slow and inefficient loading process

options.label: C
options.text: Fatigue from driving and needing a break

options.label: D
options.text: Disagreement with stevedores about the loading process

multiple-choice.question: What traditional method of shipping non-bulk cargo involved handling boxes, bales, and crates piece by piece?

options.label: A
options.text: Intermodal transportation

options.label: B
options.text: Break bulk shipping

options.label: C
options.text: Containerization

options.label: D
options.text: Globalization

multiple-choice.question: How did Malcolm McLean's concept of containerization impact the shipping industry?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased the cost of shipping and reduced efficiency

options.label: B
options.text: Reduced the time it took to load and unload ships, increasing efficiency

options.label: C
options.text: Limited the types of goods that could be shipped internationally

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased the number of jobs available in the industry

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of Malcolm McLean's first container ship, which sailed from Port Newark in 1956?

options.label: A
options.text: The Container King

options.label: B
options.text: The Global Voyager

options.label: C
options.text: The Sea Dragon

options.label: D
options.text: The Ideal X

multiple-choice.question: How did Malcolm McLean's concept of containerization contribute to the growth of globalization?

options.label: A
options.text: Reduced the variety of goods available in the global market

options.label: B
options.text: Increased the cost of international trade and reduced efficiency

options.label: C
options.text: Increased the speed and efficiency of international trade, facilitating globalization

options.label: D
options.text: Had no impact on globalization

multiple-choice.question: What was the average time it took to haul and distribute break bulk shipments in the hold, plus the time to retrieve and distribute at the other end?

options.label: A
options.text: 2 days

options.label: B
options.text: 2 weeks

options.label: C
options.text: 8 days + 8 days

options.label: D
options.text: 1 month

multiple-choice.question: What significant benefit did Malcolm McLean's concept of containerization bring to global trade?

options.label: A
options.text: Decreased international trade and increased costs

options.label: B
options.text: Increased the cost of shipping goods and reduced efficiency

options.label: C
options.text: Made it possible to move cargo from remote parts of the world at minimal cost

options.label: D
options.text: Had no impact on the way goods are transported

multiple-choice.question: What can be inferred about Malcolm McLean's personality based on his actions and decisions?

options.label: A
options.text: Primarily motivated by the desire to make a profit

options.label: B
options.text: Visionary who was willing to take risks to pursue his ideas

options.label: C
options.text: Risk-averse and hesitant to take on new challenges

options.label: D
options.text: Not interested in making a significant impact on the world

multiple-choice.question: Why is Malcolm McLean's contribution to the development of containerization important?

options.label: A
options.text: He was the first person to come up with the idea of containerization

options.label: B
options.text: He implemented his idea on a large scale

options.label: C
options.text: He revolutionized the shipping industry and facilitated the growth of globalization

options.label: D
options.text: He made a significant profit from his invention

title: Poetic stickup: Put the financial aid in the bag - Carvens Lissaint

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's primary goal in the given scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: To protest against the government

options.label: B
options.text: To obtain financial aid for education

options.label: C
options.text: To promote a new music album

options.label: D
options.text: To support a social cause

multiple-choice.question: What type of loans does the speaker specifically ask someone to get for him?

options.label: A
options.text: Unsubsidized loans

options.label: B
options.text: Subsidized loans

options.label: C
options.text: Personal loans

options.label: D
options.text: Mortgage loans

multiple-choice.question: How does the speaker feel about the current state of financial aid and education?

options.label: A
options.text: He is satisfied with the system and feels it is fair.

options.label: B
options.text: He is frustrated and feels the system is flawed and unjust.

options.label: C
options.text: He is neutral and doesn't have an opinion.

options.label: D
options.text: He is confused and doesn't understand the system.

multiple-choice.question: What historical reference does the speaker make when talking about the struggle for education?

options.label: A
options.text: The American Civil War

options.label: B
options.text: The Civil Rights Movement

options.label: C
options.text: The Thirteenth Amendment

options.label: D
options.text: The Industrial Revolution

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's tone when addressing the audience and the financial aid system?

options.label: A
options.text: Calm and polite

options.label: B
options.text: Angry and confrontational

options.label: C
options.text: Sarcastic and humorous

options.label: D
options.text: Indifferent and neutral

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker mean by "don't call it financial aid if you're not helping anyone with it"?

options.label: A
options.text: He wants to abolish financial aid entirely.

options.label: B
options.text: He believes financial aid should only be given to those who truly need it.

options.label: C
options.text: He thinks financial aid should be renamed to something more accurate.

options.label: D
options.text: He wants financial aid to be more accessible and helpful to students.

multiple-choice.question: If you were in a similar situation as the speaker, how would you approach the issue of obtaining financial aid?

options.label: A
options.text: I would protest and demand change.

options.label: B
options.text: I would try to find alternative sources of funding.

options.label: C
options.text: I would accept the current system and try to make the best of it.

options.label: D
options.text: I would seek guidance from a financial advisor.

multiple-choice.question: Analyze the speaker's use of music references and lyrics. What purpose do they serve in his message?

options.label: A
options.text: They add a touch of humor and lightheartedness to the speech.

options.label: B
options.text: They help to emphasize the speaker's emotions and frustrations.

options.label: C
options.text: They serve as a distraction from the main issue.

options.label: D
options.text: They are irrelevant to the topic of financial aid.

multiple-choice.question: Evaluate the speaker's argument that the current financial aid system is unfair and perpetuates inequality. Do you agree or disagree with his stance?

options.label: A
options.text: I agree, the system is flawed and needs reform.

options.label: B
options.text: I disagree, the system is fair and provides adequate support.

options.label: C
options.text: I partially agree, but there are also benefits to the current system.

options.label: D
options.text: I am undecided, more information is needed to form an opinion.

multiple-choice.question: Synthesize the speaker's message and propose a potential solution to the issues he raises regarding financial aid and education.

options.label: A
options.text: Implement a more need-based financial aid system.

options.label: B
options.text: Increase funding for scholarships and grants.

options.label: C
options.text: Promote financial literacy and education among students.

options.label: D
options.text: Reform the current system to prioritize accessibility and affordability.

title: The power of simple words - Terin Izil

multiple-choice.question: What phrase does Dorothy repeat in the scene described in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: "No coordinates exist like one's domicile"

options.label: B
options.text: "There's no place like home"

options.label: C
options.text: "Home is where the heart is"

options.label: D
options.text: "A house is not a home"

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, why might $10 words fail in most cases?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are too long

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are not understood by the audience

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are too formal

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are too common

multiple-choice.question: What is the main point the author is trying to make about using complex vocabulary in writing?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is always better to use simple words

options.label: B
options.text: That big words are only effective if they are understood by the audience

options.label: C
options.text: That big words should only be used in formal writing

options.label: D
options.text: That big words are necessary for good writing

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's advice for writers who are competing for space in a shrinking attention span?

options.label: A
options.text: To use more descriptive language

options.label: B
options.text: To write longer, more detailed passages

options.label: C
options.text: To get to the point already

options.label: D
options.text: To use jargon and technical terms

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the "bread and butter" of life when it comes to writing?

options.label: A
options.text: Variety

options.label: B
options.text: Brevity

options.label: C
options.text: Clarity

options.label: D
options.text: Creativity

multiple-choice.question: What can be inferred about the author's opinion on the use of thesauruses in writing?

options.label: A
options.text: That they are essential tools for all writers

options.label: B
options.text: That they are only useful for novelists

options.label: C
options.text: That they can be helpful, but should be used sparingly

options.label: D
options.text: That the author is neutral about their use, but implies that using a thesaurus to find complex words may not be effective

multiple-choice.question: How might a novelist's audience differ from the audience for other types of writing?

options.label: A
options.text: They may be more likely to be distracted

options.label: B
options.text: They may be expecting more concise language

options.label: C
options.text: They may be expecting more vivid descriptors

options.label: D
options.text: They may be expecting a lower reading level

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's attitude towards the use of complex vocabulary in writing?

options.label: A
options.text: Enthusiastic

options.label: B
options.text: Neutral

options.label: C
options.text: Skeptical

options.label: D
options.text: Disapproving

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the relationship between the use of complex vocabulary and the audience's understanding?

options.label: A
options.text: The more complex the vocabulary, the more likely the audience is to understand

options.label: B
options.text: The more complex the vocabulary, the less likely the audience is to understand

options.label: C
options.text: The complexity of the vocabulary has no impact on the audience's understanding

options.label: D
options.text: The relationship between vocabulary and understanding is not mentioned in the transcript

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's suggestion for what to do with $10 words?

options.label: A
options.text: Use them frequently in your writing

options.label: B

options.label: C

title: Symbiosis: A surprising tale of species cooperation - David Gonzales

multiple-choice.question: What term describes a partnership between two different species where both species depend on each other and benefit from the relationship?

options.label: A
options.text: Mutualism

options.label: B
options.text: Symbiosis

options.label: C
options.text: Parasitism

options.label: D
options.text: Commensalism

multiple-choice.question: In which region of the United States do whitebark pine trees primarily grow?

options.label: A
options.text: Eastern states

options.label: B
options.text: Western states, including Wyoming and Montana

options.label: C
options.text: Southern states

options.label: D
options.text: Northeastern states

multiple-choice.question: What role do squirrels play in the ecosystem of whitebark pine trees?

options.label: A
options.text: They only feed on the cones of the trees

options.label: B
options.text: They gnaw the cones from the upper branches, causing them to fall to the ground, and then bury them in piles

options.label: C
options.text: They disperse seeds by carrying them to new locations

options.label: D
options.text: They provide shelter for other animals

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the way Clark's nutcrackers store seeds?

options.label: A
options.text: They store seeds in their nests

options.label: B
options.text: They store seeds in a pouch in their throat

options.label: C
options.text: They store seeds in tree cavities

options.label: D
options.text: They store seeds in underground burrows

multiple-choice.question: How do Clark's nutcrackers contribute to the reproduction of whitebark pine trees?

options.label: A
options.text: They pollinate the trees

options.label: B
options.text: They replant the trees by caching seeds in the ground

options.label: C
options.text: They protect the trees from pests and diseases

options.label: D
options.text: They provide nutrients to the trees through their droppings

multiple-choice.question: How do Clark's nutcrackers remember the location of their cached seeds?

options.label: A
options.text: They use their sense of smell

options.label: B
options.text: They use landmarks on the landscape, such as trees, stumps, and rocks, to triangulate to the caches

options.label: C
options.text: They use a mental map

options.label: D
options.text: They follow a specific route to recall the locations

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how the symbiosis between Clark's nutcrackers and whitebark pine trees has led to evolutionary changes in both species?

options.label: A
options.text: The birds have developed shorter beaks, and the trees have developed smaller cones

options.label: B
options.text: The birds have developed long, tough beaks, and the trees have developed branches that sweep upwards with cones at the ends

options.label: C
options.text: The birds have developed stronger wings, and the trees have developed deeper roots

options.label: D
options.text: The birds have developed sharper eyesight, and the trees have developed thicker trunks

multiple-choice.question: If the population of Clark's nutcrackers were to decline significantly, what would likely happen to the population of whitebark pine trees?

options.label: A
options.text: The population of whitebark pine trees would increase

options.label: B
options.text: The population of whitebark pine trees would remain the same

options.label: C
options.text: The population of whitebark pine trees would decline

options.label: D
options.text: The population of whitebark pine trees would become extinct

multiple-choice.question: How do grizzlies and black bears benefit from the symbiosis between Clark's nutcrackers and whitebark pine trees?

options.label: A
options.text: They hunt and eat Clark's nutcrackers

options.label: B
options.text: They find and eat the cached seeds of Clark's nutcrackers

options.label: C
options.text: They feed on the cones of the whitebark pine trees

options.label: D
options.text: They have no role in the symbiosis

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary benefit of the symbiosis between Clark's nutcrackers and whitebark pine trees for the ecosystem as a whole?

options.label: A
options.text: It provides food for other animals, such as grizzlies and black bears

options.label: B
options.text: It allows the trees to grow taller and stronger

options.label: C
options.text: It enables the birds to store seeds for the winter

options.label: D
options.text: It promotes cooperation and mutual benefit between two species, leading to a healthier and more diverse ecosystem

multiple-choice.question: How many seeds can a Clark's nutcracker store in its throat pouch?

options.label: A
options.text: Up to 20 seeds

options.label: B
options.text: Up to 50 seeds

options.label: C
options.text: Up to 80 seeds

options.label: D
options.text: Up to 100 seeds

multiple-choice.question: How many seeds can Clark's nutcrackers gather in the autumn?

options.label: A
options.text: Up to 10,000 seeds

options.label: B
options.text: Up to 50,000 seeds

options.label: C
options.text: Up to 90,000 seeds

options.label: D

title: How many universes are there? - Chris Anderson

multiple-choice.question: Approximately how many stars are in the Milky Way galaxy?

options.text: 1 billion

options.label: B
options.text: 100 billion

options.label: C
options.text: 400 billion

options.label: D
options.text: 1 trillion

options.text: 10 feet by 10 feet, one foot deep

options.label: B
options.text: 30 feet by 30 feet, three feet deep

options.label: C
options.text: 100 feet by 100 feet, 10 feet deep

options.text: 1 mile by 1 mile, 100 feet deep

options.label: A
options.text: Up to 100 universes

options.label: B
options.text: Up to 1,000 universes

options.label: C
options.text: Up to 10 to the 500 universes

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: String theory

options.label: C
options.text: General relativity

options.label: D
options.text: Classical mechanics

options.text: Finite and bounded

options.label: B

options.text: Finite but unbounded

options.label: D

options.text: Proving its validity

options.label: B
options.text: Understanding its mathematical framework

options.label: C
options.text: Interpreting its results and implications

options.label: D
options.text: Applying it to real-world problems

multiple-choice.question: According to some physicists, what is one possible way to interpret the results of quantum theory?

options.label: A
options.text: Assuming the existence of a single, deterministic universe

options.label: B
options.text: Assuming the existence of multiple parallel universes

options.label: C
options.text: Assuming the existence of a non-deterministic universe

options.label: D
options.text: Assuming the existence of a universe with a fixed number of dimensions

multiple-choice.question: What is the range of possible answers to the question of how many universes there are?

options.label: A
options.text: 1 to 10

options.label: C
options.text: 0 to infinity

options.label: D
options.text: 1 to 1 trillion

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential implication of the multiverse theory on our understanding of reality?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It suggests that our universe is one of many, but they are all similar

options.label: C
options.text: It suggests that our universe is one of many, and they may have different properties and laws

options.label: D
options.text: It suggests that our universe is an illusion

multiple-choice.question: What is the current state of agreement among scientists and philosophers on the question of how many universes there are?

options.label: A
options.text: There is a broad consensus on a single answer

options.label: B
options.text: There are two or three competing theories, but most scientists agree on one of them

options.label: C
options.text: There is no agreement, and the answer could be anywhere between zero and infinity

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.text: Armand Fizeau

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Friction

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: 500 miles

options.label: C
options.text: 750 miles

options.label: D
options.text: 1000 miles

options.label: B
options.text: The speed of light

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: That science is too complicated for non-experts to understand

options.label: B
options.text: That science is only for experts

options.label: C
options.text: That science is a dynamic and accessible field that anyone can contribute to

options.label: A
options.text: That science is only for geniuses and experts

options.label: B
options.text: That science is a closed, black box that only experts can understand

options.label: C
options.text: That anyone can make discoveries and contribute to science with curiosity and hard thinking

options.label: D
options.text: That science is too complicated for non-experts to understand
